q1.query: What FTE range must GEO appointments fall within to be covered by the GEO contract?
q1.answer: This information is not available in the provided documents.

q2.query: How many days before the semester must appointment letters be issued?
q2.answer: The letter of appointment must be issued no later than 45 days before the start of the appointment [Source 1]. However, if the appointment is made less than 45 days before or 45 days after the beginning of the semester, the letter of appointment shall be issued as soon as practicable [Source 1].

q3.query: Are tuition and fee waivers guaranteed for GEO-covered employees?
q3.answer: Yes, tuition and fee waivers are guaranteed for GEO-covered employees. Assistants covered under the GEO agreement have specific fees and assessments waived, including the "Service Fee", "Health Service Fee", "Academic Facilities and Maintenance Assessment", and "Library and Information Technology Assessment" [Source 5]. Additionally, for international students covered by the agreement, the University waives "$65 of the International Student Fee for each Fall and Spring semester" [Source 5]. The union also reserves the right to bargain General Fee increases exceeding $25 per semester [Source 5]. Any new fee created after the agreement is ratified and executed will be waived for the duration of the agreement [Source 5].

q4.query: What fees must the University waive for GEO members?
q4.answer:
For Assistants covered under the GEO agreement, the University shall waive the following fees and assessments [Source 4]:
*   Service Fee
*   Health Service Fee
*   Academic Facilities and Maintenance Assessment
*   Library and Information Technology Assessment

For international students covered under the GEO agreement, the University shall waive $65 of the International Student Fee for each Fall and Spring semester during the term of the agreement [Source 4]. Any increase to the International Fee during the term of this Agreement shall also be waived [Source 4].

Any new fee created after the ratification and execution of this Agreement shall be waived for the duration of this Agreement [Source 4].

During the term of this Agreement, if the General Fee increases more than $25 per semester, the Union reserves the right to bargain the additional increase [Source 4].

q5.query: What is the process for resolving grievances under the GEO collective bargaining agreement?
q5.answer: The GEO collective bargaining agreement includes a section dedicated to the "Grievance Procedure" [Source 2]. However, the specifics of the grievance procedure are not detailed in the provided excerpts [Source 2].

q6.query: What are the minimum salaries for Assistant, Associate, and Full Professors under the CBA?
q6.answer: This information is not available in the provided documents. While the documents discuss appointments, promotions, and salary increases for faculty, they do not specify the minimum salaries for Assistant, Associate, and Full Professors [Source 10, Source 9].

q7.query: How is merit pay determined and allocated for tenure-track faculty?
q7.answer: This information is not available in the provided documents.

q8.query: What protections does the agreement provide regarding academic freedom?
q8.answer:
The agreement provides the following protections regarding academic freedom:

*   **TT-Faculty and NTT-Faculty Agreements:**
    *   It is the University's policy to "maintain and encourage full freedom within the law of inquiry, discourse, teaching, research, and publication" [Source 4, 6].
    *   The University aims to "protect any member of the bargaining unit against influences, from within or without the University, which would restrict the member’s exercise of these freedoms in the member’s area of scholarly research and interest" [Source 4, 6].
    *   Faculty members may exercise the same freedoms as other citizens without institutional censorship or discipline but should be mindful of accuracy, forthrightness, and dignity [Source 4, 6].
    *   A faculty member who believes their academic freedom has been violated is entitled to a hearing before the Committee on Academic Freedom and Tenure of the campus Senate, following established rules of procedure [Source 4, 6].
*   **GEO Agreement:**
    *   The University and the Union agree that "academic freedom is one of the values essential to higher education" [Source 3].
    *   The University retains sole and exclusive control over academic judgments concerning courses, curriculum, instruction, content of courses, methods of instruction, instructional materials, assignments, class size, and grading policies [Source 3].
    *   The University retains sole and exclusive control to determine all academic policies, procedures, rules and regulations in regard to assistants’ status as students including, but not limited to, all questions of academic standing, intellectual integrity, and any matter relating to academic progress in a university educational program [Source 3].
    *   The University retains sole and exclusive control to make academic evaluations and determinations as to the fulfillment of degree requirements, including the relationship between work performance and progress toward degree requirements [Source 3].
    *   The Union retains the right to negotiate mandatory subjects of bargaining [Source 3].

q9.query: What process governs non-reappointment or tenure decisions?
q9.answer:
The following processes govern non-reappointment or tenure decisions:

*   **Tenure-Track Faculty:** Initial tenure track faculty appointments for more than fifty percent (50%) of full-time service are made by the Board of Trustees upon an advisory vote of the faculty in the relevant academic unit and recommendation of the campus Chancellor/Vice President and President [Source 4, Source 7]. The Board of Trustees is the only body that can promote or award tenure to tenure track faculty [Source 7].
*   **Non-Reappointment of Assistant Professors:** Assistant professors on a definite-term appointment may be given written notice of non-reappointment, except during the last year of the probationary period [Source 7]. Written notice must be given not less than twelve months before the expiration of the appointment, or a terminal contract for one additional year of academic service must be offered [Source 7]. If the assistant professor is in their first year of academic service, written notice of non-reappointment must be given no later than March 1 and need not be accompanied by an offer of a terminal contract; if given after March 1, it must include a terminal contract [Source 7].
*   **Non-Reappointment, Dismissal, Layoff, and Recall during Multi-year Contracts (NTT Faculty):** A bargaining unit member with a multi-year appointment may have their appointment terminated during the term of a multi-year appointment if the specific work they have been performing is to be reduced or discontinued and/or the courses for which they were employed to teach are to be reduced or discontinued [Source 6]. The affected faculty member may choose to be placed on a recall list for up to three academic years [Source 6].
*   **Notice of Non-Reappointment (NTT Faculty):** If the University has not finalized its decision regarding reappointment or non-reappointment, the affected faculty member will be informed by May 15 [Source 6]. Notice of reappointment or non-reappointment shall be provided by July 16 [Source 6]. Bargaining unit members employed as faculty for at least ten years will receive notice of reappointment or non-reappointment one year before the end of their contracts [Source 6].

q10.query: What grievance and arbitration process applies to tenure-track faculty disputes?
q10.answer:
The grievance and arbitration process for tenure-track faculty disputes is outlined in several sections of the "TT-FACULTY 2023-final.txt" document [Source 2, Source 4, Source 5, Source 6].

Here's a breakdown:

*   **Discipline and Dismissal (Tenured Faculty):** The University of Illinois Statutes and related campus human resource policies and procedures govern discipline or dismissal of tenured faculty, not the grievance and arbitration process outlined in Article XVI of the agreement [Source 5].
*   **Arbitration Hearing:** A single arbitrator will hear the grievance. Both parties can be represented and have the right to submit evidence, testimony, and arguments [Source 6].
*   **Arbitrator Selection:** The parties must promptly notify the arbitrator of their selection [Source 6].

q11.query: What is the minimum salary for instructors, lecturers, and clinical assistant professors?
q11.answer: Effective August 16, 2022, the minimum salary for full-time bargaining unit members with the rank of Instructor, Lecturer, or Clinical Assistant Professor will not be lower than $60,000 [Source 7].

q12.query: How are promotion and reappointment decisions handled for NTT faculty?
q12.answer:
The following information is available regarding appointment, reappointment, and promotion decisions for Non-Tenure Track (NTT) faculty:

*   **Article IX** of the agreement covers "Appointment, Reappointment, Promotion, Layoff and Recall" for NTT faculty [Source 1, 3].
*   **Article IX, A** discusses NTT Faculty Appointments [Source 3].
*   Changes in rank to a Teaching Professor shall not affect salaries or timelines for multi-year contracts [Source 4].
*   Bargaining unit members who change appointments will be considered for promotion under norms established by the candidate’s academic unit in compliance with the criteria and guidelines developed by the University Senate and colleges for non-tenured academic ranks using the “Teaching” modifier [Source 4].
*   However, Article IX of the Agreement does not apply to Bridge to Faculty Program Scholars in the bargaining unit [Source 10]. Appointment and reappointment of Bridge to Faculty Program Scholars shall follow the guidelines created by the University for the Bridge to Faculty Program [Source 10].

q13.query: What side letter provisions exist regarding teaching professor ranks?
q13.answer: There is a "Side Letter on Teaching Professor Ranks" [Source 1, 5]. According to the University Senate resolution passed on April 21, 2022, faculty with "Clinical" or "Research" modifiers will not be required to convert to the "Teaching" modifier as a condition for reappointment [Source 1]. Academic units adopting the "Teaching" modifier for non-tenured ranks of assistant professor, associate professor, and professor must review and revise their workload expectations, Annual Evaluation criteria, and Promotion Norms [Source 1]. This review must be completed within a year of signing the agreement [Source 1]. Individual units can apply for position changes for bargaining unit members to the appropriate Teaching professor rank if the bargaining unit member (1) will perform the job responsibilities of a position bearing the newly adopted “Teaching” modifier, (2) wishes to be considered for the appropriate Teaching professor rank, and (3) possesses the degree required by the University for that rank [Source 1]. Changes in rank shall not affect bargaining unit member salaries and timelines for multi-year contracts [Source 2].

q14.query: Under what conditions can NTT faculty be laid off or recalled?
q14.answer:
The document "[Source 1]" and "[Source 4]" indicates that Article IX of the agreement covers "Appointment, Reappointment, Promotion, Layoff and Recall" of Non-Tenure Track (NTT) faculty.

[Source 3] states that if reduced or discontinued work/courses are reinstated, faculty on the recall list will be offered reinstatement to complete their multi-year appointment. Gaps in service due to termination and reinstatement will not disrupt consecutive years of service for promotion or multi-year contract eligibility [Source 3].

q15.query: What professional leave options are available to NTT faculty under the agreement?
q15.answer: The University and the Union have agreed that the Office of the Provost will continue to work with the Faculty Senate to develop and implement a policy regarding the eligibility of NTT faculty to apply for professional leave, and shall report upon the progress toward this policy annually during the term of this contract [Source 3].
